Caring For Children And Adults With Autism In The Acute Setting / MSEPO-20249/ 1.0
Page  of
Introduction
The Trust is committed to improving access and services for patients with autism.

It is vital that patients on the autistic spectrum are identified and supported and that this patient minority group have the opportunity to be involved in their care whatever their age, gender, sexuality, disability, race or religion.

The Trust recognises and values parents/carers as the experts in the well- being and recovery of the patient with autism, and, promotes working together collaboratively to ensure equal health outcomes.

Patients with autism who require pre-admission preparation and/or de-sensitisation to enable health facilitation within their home setting must have this provided by appropriately qualified staff following clear pathways based on best practice.
The Trust recognises that effective communication and record keeping between staff, the patient with autism and parent/carers is essential.

The Trust recognises that parents/carers are viewed as the experts in the management of patients' with autism and staff may need to listen and learn from them regarding the best approach on individual care and management.
The Trust recognises that procedures will need to be adapted where necessary to ensure their effective delivery, including modifications to the setting in which assessment and treatment is delivered.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
This policy applies to the practice of Trust staff in the provision of services to patients with autism that are accessing wards/departments.

The policy is to support Trust staff who are providing essential health care to young people and adult patients on the autistic spectrum; to enable effective communication on all levels in order to make the autistic patient hospital episode as safe and as uncomplicated as possible.
Throughout the policy the term “autism” is being used as an umbrella term and therefore consideration should be given to the range of disorders with features of all autistic spectrum conditions.
Definitions

table_items.text: Autism is defined as a lifelong neuro-development disability which is characterised by:
Impairments in reciprocal social interactions. Impairments in verbal and non-verbal communication skills. Impairment in imagination resulting in stereotyped behaviour, interests and activities.

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities

MSE joint Safeguarding Committee – To provide assurance to the trust in regards to compliance with all local and national guidance regarding service provision for patients with Autism in an acute healthcare environment.

Chief Executive – As the Trust's accountable officer has overall responsibility for ensuring MSE Trust has robust, complete and up to date procedures in place to govern and guide activities so that legal and national requirements are met.
Associate Director Safeguarding services:

To ensure the development and leadership of a robust culture of safeguarding practice across the MSE group, providing strategic and corporate direction including complex professional advice on matters relating to safeguarding individuals at risk:

To lead the organisation on collaborative working practices across both agency and geographical boundaries, with providers of health and social care and other partner agencies, to provide a seamless approach to safeguarding individuals at risk. An approach that incorporates a holistic family approach to any individual at risk of or being abused

Learning Disability Service Lead –To act as the strategic lead in the development of equitable and high-quality health care for adults with learning disabilities within acute care across the MSB Group.

Learning Disability Acute Liaison Nurse Specialist – To provide advie and support to clinical areas to meet the needs of people with Autism when they are admitted / attend for treatment / appointments. They have specialist expertise which will enable clinical teams to plan and support the patients care to ensure that they have a positive experience.

Matrons - will in the absence of the ward manager review the decisions made by ward staff and assess the appropriateness of the reasonable adjustments that have been made. When required the matron will authorise additional resources. Matrons will be involved in the escalation of concerns, and support teams to plan and deliver appropriate care thus ensuring positive patient experience.
Ward / Department Manager - will review the decisions made by ward staff and assess the appropriateness of the reasonable adjustments that have been made.

Ward/Department staff - The admitting nurse needs to undertake a comprehensive assessment, to identify individuals needs such as communication and support needs to ensure continuity of care and to maintain appropriate levels of support during the hospital admission.
Autism is defined as a lifelong neuro-development disability
Autism is defined as a lifelong neuro-development disability which is characterised by:
Impairments in reciprocal social interactions
Impairments in verbal and non-verbal communication skills
Impairment in imagination resulting in stereotyped behaviour, interests and activities
The characteristic behaviours of autism spectrum disorders may or may not always be apparent in infancy, but usually become obvious during early childhood.

Autistic Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is a neurological disorder that affects nerves, nervous system and the brain. This can manifest as impairments in communication, motor skills, social interaction, imagination and behaviour, and although some have a learning disability studies have proven that many people with autism have a higher than average IQ.
In addition, people with autism may experience over or under-sensitivity to sounds tastes, smells, lights or colours. They may also become highly distressed with changes to routine.
Some people with autism are able to lead independent lives with little support, whilst others need on going specialist support throughout their lives.
Differential Diagnosis
5.6.1 Some conditions may have symptoms similar to autism.
5.6.2 There are related syndromes/disorders that manifest behaviours similar to those of autism and/or are more prevalent in individuals with autism:
Cornelia de Lange Syndrome
Fragile X Syndrome
Williams Syndrome
Landau-Kleffner Syndrome
Tuberous Sclerosis.
Prader-Willi Syndrome
Retts Syndrome
Tourettes Syndrome
Identification of the Patient with Autism:

5.7.1  Patients with autism need to be identified as early as possible. Staff will need to use good communication and observation skills to elicit this information and once ASD has been confirmed then a referral should be made to the Hospital Liaison Nurse Specialist for patient flagging IT System, tracking and audit purposes.
Person Centred Approach to Care

5.8.1 Patients with ASD may have a hospital passport. This document can support staff to meet a patients individualised needs. If they do not have a hospital passport one can be downloaded from the hospital website and completed by the patient or someone who knows them well.
5.8.2 Choices and treatment options are available and need to reflect the needs, abilities and aspirations of the patient with autism and their family/carers.

5.8.3 Following assessment if it is deemed that the person with autism does not have the capacity to make decisions, the Trust has a duty to act in that patient's best interests. Therefore healthcare professionals should follow the Department of Health's advice on consent and the code of practice that accompanies the Mental Capacity Act set out in the Trust's Mental Capacity Act Policy.

5.8.4 As far as possible all assessments of needs should be carried with the support of a professional who has a good knowledge of autism. Reasonable adjustments may need to be made to the assessment process to enable the adult with autism to participate.

5.8.5 Using the information based from the comprehensive assessment and physical examination, and clinical judgement, staff must always consider carrying out further investigations and other medical tests depending on the individual signs and symptoms i.e. a sudden onset of challenging behaviour, change in usual patterns of behaviour, sudden change in weight, or suspicion that the person might be in pain and is unable to communicate this.
General Principles of Caring for the Patient with Autism:
All staff working with children and adults with autism should:
Make reasonable adjustments where appropriate
Work in partnership with adults with autism and where appropriate, with their families, carers
Ensure a person centred approach is used
Offer on-going compassionate support and care respectfully
Take time to build a trusting, supportive, empathic, and non-judgemental relationship as an essential part of care
Be flexible in their approach and timing of care delivery whilst understanding the limitations of the person with autism
Ensure a collaborative, multiagency approach across health teams in order to make it easier to provide a coordinated and equitable service throughout the period of care

5.9.1 Each person with ASD are unique in presentation, as are their habits, behaviours, likes and dislikes and this should be taken account of. Good communication between healthcare professionals and people with autism and their families, partners and carers is essential.
5.9.2 Information that is given on support and care should be accessible for the person with autism and any other additional needs.

5.9.3 Families and carers living with a person with autism become experts in their condition and its management. They are an invaluable source of advice and support. In particular they can provide a 'hospital passport' for adults with autism, which includes information for all staff about the person's care and support needs.
5.9.4 If the person with autism agrees, families, partners and carers should have the opportunity to be involved in decisions about support and care.

5.9.5 In an emergency situation, the patient with autism, their families and carers need information about the person's condition to be given quickly and calmly so that they can become involved, as appropriate, in planning their treatment and on-going care.

5.9.6 When the person with autism is transferred between settings, both the person and their family/carers need to know whom to contact for information. Ensure the hospital passport is transferred with them.
People with Autism Requiring Hospital Admission or in an Emergency

5.10.1 Coming into the hospital setting or any unfamiliar care setting will be a particularly anxious time for people with ASD; they will often have complex problems needing a carefully integrated and co-ordinated care plan for their admission. Where admission is planned anxiety can be greatly reduced if staff:
Refer to “Hospital Passport”
Make a referral to alert the Hospital Liaison Nurse Specialist of pending admission if appropriate.
Ensure that reasonable adjustments are in place so that the complex needs can be met across all settings
5.10.2 In the case of emergency admissions, the patient with autism will need to be assessed and treated in a timely manner. Additional risks and complications can be reduced if staff:
Refer to “Hospital Passport”
Alert the Hospital Liaison Nurse Specialist of the emergency admission
For additional support/advise/information contact specialist teams

5.10.3 Some people with autism who have more complex needs requiring skilled multidisciplinary input from a number of different agencies/department will need an identified person who coordinates care.
Making Reasonable Adjustments
5.11.1 To deliver appropriate and effective medical care, the history, and approach to the patient, physical evaluation, and treatment options must be considered in the context of the persons ASD.
5.11.2 Making reasonable adjustments means changing the way services are delivered to make them accessible to disabled people. A person with autism will find it difficult to use the health services.

5.11.3 Reasonable adjustments are a key part of the Disability Discrimination Act 1995 and can be central to enabling any persons with a disability access the services they need. Potential areas for Staff to consider include:
5.11.4 Making adjustments or adaptations to premises or the environment to take account of sensory factors and hypersensitivities including sensory overload, such as providing a quiet area.

5.11.5 Making adjustments to processes, such as scheduling appointments at less busy times. Try to give the patient with an ASD the first or last appointment of the day. People with an ASD find waiting around for an appointment extremely stressful and often, more time is required for outpatient appointments.

5.11.6 Making adjustments to communications, for example this document can be made available in accessible formats e.g. Large Print, Easy Read or Audio. (downloadable resources can be accessed via Trust website)
Encouraging support from families and carers by being flexible over accepting support and visiting times.
5.12.1 Wherever possible familiarise the person with the hospital setting and staff.

5.12.2 Staff should allow ample time whilst talking before touching or examining the individual, allowing the person to manipulate instruments and materials, keeping instructions simple, using visual cues and supports, slowing down the pace, exaggerating social cues, and having family and carers or familiar staff available may be helpful in reducing the obstacles to health care provision presented by the person's difficulties with social interaction and communication.
Understanding the Patient with Autism
5.13.1 The best intervention for staff is preparation. If you know that a patient with autism will be coming into the hospital environment then offer them (and parents/caregivers)
the opportunity to tour your department giving them time to de-sensitise. Encourage them to ask questions, touch equipment and "get used to" the way things are.

5.13.2 Communicate with the patient at a level he or she can understand and explain all assessments and treatments. Many people with ASD crave information and will want to know more about what's happening. Explain those "how's" and "whys" as best you can, and be prepared to discuss specifics. If they understand why a procedure is being done, they're more likely to allow it. It must make sense to them.

5.13.3 People with ASD are sometimes comforted by familiarity. Encourage the person to bring a transitional object i.e.: a security toy or blanket with them. Some patients with ASD might become agitated when a strange object touches their skin. Scratchy blankets or disposable sheets can be uncomfortable, while softer, cloth sheets and flannel blankets generally are better tolerated. The best option is to allow these patients to bring their own blanket along.

5.13.4 Always tell patients with ASD where (and why) you need to touch them during an exam or treatment, especially when you are about to touch them with medical equipment. Metal, plastic or other objects of different temperatures can feel like pinpricks to people with ASD. Adhesive tape or ECG patches also can be difficult for autistic patients with tactile sensitivity.

5.13.5 Some patients with ASD can be calmed by moderate pressure (wrapping a blanket around themselves, several blankets piled on top the patient, hugging (familiar people), but they can be agitated by "light" touches like the pressure of only a light sheet, the sensation of air blowing on them, taps on the shoulder, etc. For these reasons, you're more likely to have more problems wrapping a BP cuff around a patient's arm than by inflating it. Oxygen masks and a nasal cannula also might not be well-tolerated because of the doubly uncomfortable sensation of blowing air and having something on/over their faces. Non-invasive techniques should be considered where ever possible.

5.13.6 Trauma patients with ASD require constant patience and reassurance. Develop an early and calm rapport with trauma patients, especially if they must be immobilized. Many people with autism have had negative experiences with restraints and are likely to make things worse by fighting them. Again, explain every assessment and treatment before it happens, as well as everything they're likely to see, hear and feel during the extrication and/or splinting procedure.

5.13.7 Innovation is the key to successfully transporting a trauma patient with ASD. Make sure equipment fits snugly; this will be easier to tolerate than something that rubs or fits loosely. However, many have problems with cervical collars (regardless of the fit) because they are unable to tolerate something against the base of their chins/necks. Others can't stand the feeling of head straps across their foreheads.
5.13.8 Watch your language—literally. People with autism tend to take everything literally.
5.13.9 Double meanings, slang and joking that everyone else takes for granted can be confusing to a person with autism.
5.13.10 Management should focus not only on the person with autism but also on the family/carers for it is recognised that parents/carers will play a key role in effective treatment.
Sensory Overload

5.14.1 For people with autism, the experience of being in a hospital setting can be overwhelming. Remember that hospital settings are loud. Hospital interiors echo with noise that is made worse when too many people are crowding inside and talking all at once. If patients with ASD suddenly become agitated or "zone out," give consideration to sensory overload as a cause, this is because:
5.14.2 Many people on the autistic spectrum have heightened sensory abilities that are difficult to ignore
5.14.3 Increased sensitivities to auditory, tactile and visual stimuli are common and only get worse in a crisis situation
5.14.4 They might seem to be zoning out, but they are actually drawing on coping mechanisms to deal with everything around them

5.14.5 Patients with ASD are more likely to: flap, scream, rock and play with their hands, etc when they feel overwhelmed by sensory stimuli. They're doing what they need to do to cope. Although others who are described as high-functioning autistics cope instead by withdrawing (plugging their ears, closing their eyes, etc).

5.14.6 People with ASD might appear mesmerized by on-scene lights and noise. Many have ultra-sensitive hearing and can detect sounds not always apparent to others. Emergency lights emit high-pitched, "whistle" sounds (akin to fingernails on a blackboard). Portable generators, helicopters, sirens and other loud noises also can cause them to "withdraw" into themselves to escape it. Even the “quiet" ceiling fans can be overwhelming to people with ASD because of their experience of the fan- induced breeze and the "flashing lights" which are generated by the blades revolving.
5.14.7 Dealing with sensory issues - Staff can help by making the following reasonable adjustments:

5.14.8 The AC/heating unit's noise is compounded when that air is blown on people. Turn the vents upward, away from the patients. If they still can't tolerate the noise, consider turning off the AC/heating unit. Many people with autism are more tolerant of temperature changes than they are of noise

5.14.9 Interior lighting might become an issue, for two sensory reasons. Many patients with autism can both see and hear the 60-cycle frequency of fluorescent lights and can become agitated if one of those lights is wearing out (the cycle is out of sync from other lights). Although some can ignore flickering lights, most people with autism cannot. Staff should simply turn them off

5.14.10 People with autism can focus on everything, and seemingly on nothing. They appreciate order and if something's not "right" i.e. tangled ECG monitor cords, sloppy IV tape jobs, wadded sheets/blankets, general disorganization, etc they may focus on
this and become distressed. Staff should keep the working environment in an orderly and tidy fashion which will help to alleviate distress
Managing Difficult Behaviours
5.15.1 Identifying the correct interventions and monitoring their use

5.15.2 It is important for staff to bear in mind that behaviour has a function and that there could be a number of reasons for it and work systematically in addressing these. These may include difficulty in processing information, unstructured time, over- sensitivity (hyper) or under-sensitivity (hypo) to something, a change in routine or physical reasons like feeling unwell, tired or hungry. Not being able to communicate these difficulties can lead to anxiety, anger and frustration, and then to an outburst of challenging behaviour.
5.15.3 When discussing and deciding on care and interventions with young people /adults with autism, Staff should take into account the nature of support needed to access and carry out interventions.
5.15.4 It is important when using any of the strategies that the individual is also provided with opportunities to develop skills to communicate their needs more appropriately.
5.15.5 Always build on the strengths of the person with ASD – use positive reinforcement where ever possible.

5.15.6 Although these kinds of behaviours can be extremely challenging, it is really important for staff to try and keep as calm as possible so that the individual is unable to ‘feed' off your reaction. It is also important to be consistent in your approach and for the other adults around to use the same consistent approach.
5.15.7 Useful Strategies for dealing with Pinching, Kicking, Slapping, Biting, Skin picking

5.15.8 It is helpful for staff to use visual aids to help with communication and show the individual the sequence of events and routine for the day. Use accessible pictorial information as a prompt and reminder of rules.

5.15.9 Staff should prepare the individual for meeting unfamiliar people by showing photographs or use of alternative visual aids. Explain when they will see them and introduce the unfamiliar person in small stages.
5.15.10 Staff should prepare the individual for any changes in routine.
5.15.11 It may be helpful for staff to suggest the use of ear defenders to block out noise and sunglasses to reduce light, try also to reduce any strong smells.
5.15.12 Staff can create and encourage opportunities for sensory stimulation, e.g. play- dough, clapping hands, singing a clapping song/rhyme, watching favourite DVD's etc.

5.15.13 Staff should state kindly but firmly using a calm, monotone voice, without showing any emotion: “(say the person's name) hands down/feet down. No pinching, slapping, kicking” and then redirect them – using distraction techniques as above.

5.15.14 Although Infection control services advocate “bare below the elbow” for infection prevention reasons where appropriate when dealing with the individual patient, Staff should wear clothes which will offer some protection to areas of the body targeted. I.e. a cardigan with long sleeves over their uniform for the short period needed for care intervention.
5.15.15 Where possible staff should access training on “break away” and “blocking” techniques.
Strategies for self-injuries behaviours:

5.16.1 Staff will need to be aware that people with autism who have complex needs and who have concurrent learning disabilities are more likely to engage in self-injurious behaviours. It is likely that they will present with self-injurious behaviours during times of stress, illness or change. It is never appropriate to ignore severe self-injurious behaviour. Self-injurious behaviours may present as:
Head banging
Eye gouging
Biting
Throwing themselves down hard onto the floor
Hair pulling

5.16.2 In the case of head banging on a hard surface, staff need to have a cushion or pillow ready to place between the surface and the individuals head. (It is also possible to get removable padding that is placed temporarily on the floors or walls to minimise injury)
5.16.3 In the case of throwing oneself down hard onto the floor, staff should consider placing mattresses on the floors.

5.16.4 In the case of hand or arm biting and hair pulling, then staff should re-direct the individual immediately to another activity that is incompatible with the self-injury i.e. an activity that requires both hands or consider providing an alternative object to bite down on.

5.16.5 Staff should try to keep responses to incidents of self-injurious behaviour low key, by limiting verbal comments, facial expressions and other displays of emotion, as these may inadvertently reinforce the behaviour. Try to speak calmly and clearly and keep facial expressions neutral.
5.16.6 Again staff should remove or reduce unpleasant sensory input i.e: sounds, smells or sights.
5.16.7 Staff should always consider physical cause and provide relief for physical discomfort i.e. analgesics if the individual has an infection.
Restraint

5.17.1 Light physical guidance may be provided if the individual is experiencing difficulties stopping the behaviour using as little force as possible, gently guide the persons hand away from head. Immediately try to redirect attention to another activity (as described above) and be prepared to provide physical guidance again if the individual attempts to re-commence self-injurious behaviour. This approach must be used with extreme caution as it may escalate the behaviour or cause the individual to target others.

5.17.2 Some self-injurious behaviour can place the individual at serious risk of harm. In these instances, it may be appropriate for staff to explore the use of physical restraints such as arm splints or helmets to protect the individual against injury but always as a last resort.

5.17.3 Staff should be aware that physical restraints do not actually address the cause of the presenting behaviours, so it is essential that they are never used in isolation without attempts at communication skills with which the overall aim is to address the function of the behaviour.

5.17.4 Restraining people who lack capacity to consent is governed by the Mental Capacity Act 2005 (MCA 2005). Staff using restraint is required by law to have regard to the Mental Capacity Act 2005 Code of Practice. Treatment and proportionate restraint is lawful providing it is deemed to be in the person's best interest.

5.17.5 People with autism who are distressed and lack capacity often pull intravenous tubes, probes and catheters from body cavities, which need to be reinserted by hospital staff. Constantly replacing them can exacerbate the distress for the patient. If the patient is incapable of making decisions, the Trust staff has a duty to act in that patient's best interests.

5.17.6 If the person with autism is finding it difficult to cope with the demands being placed upon them then staff should withdraw. If it is at all possible then come back to the care activity again later when the person is feeling calmer.

5.17.7 With regards to 16  year old young people with autism who lack capacity staff should be aware that consent can be given by a person with parental authority or by the court even when the young person is refusing treatment. However, the MCA2 documentation will still need to be in place. Parental authority it needs to be clear that:
5.17.8 Parents with authority have limits to this right for children  or older when agreeing to or refusing health care, and legal advice would need to be sought.

5.17.9 Staff will be aware that they have an overriding duty to act in the best interests of the 16- 17 year old and when making decisions regarding treatment, the young person should be involved in the decision as much as possible, depending on their level of understanding.

5.17.10 Judgments about competence and capacity can only be made on an individual basis. In complex cases it is best practice for a referral to be made to the specialist clinician to assist with assessment and offer advice on competence.
5.17.11 It is vital to document carefully all the factors contributing to a judgement of competence and keep the information in the person's health notes.
Training Requirements
The Hospital Liaison Nurse Specialist offers support, information and training to staff in order to develop a better understanding of the needs of people with learning disabilities/autism.

Autism awareness training is available to all staff at the Trust, which ensures that staff can become familiar with the disorder, its impact, the importance of partnership working and individual case management
Monitoring and Audit

Appendix 1: An Overview of the Six Difficulties Associated with Autistic Traits and Representative Groups
COMMUNICATION:
Unusual social interaction and reciprocal communication behaviours; Spoken language may be unusual in several ways:
Very limited use
Monotonous tone;
Repetitive speech, frequent use of stereotyped (learnt) phrases, content
dominated by excessive information on topics of own interest;
Talking 'at' others rather than sharing a two-way conversation;
Responses to others can seem rude or inappropriate.
INTERACTIONS WITH OTHERS:
Reduced or absent awareness of personal space, or unusually intolerant of
people entering their personal space;
Long-standing difficulties in reciprocal social communication and interaction with few close friends or reciprocal relationships;
Reduced or absent understanding of friendship; often an unsuccessful desire
to have friends (although may find it easier with adults or younger children);
Social isolation and apparent preference for aloneness;
Reduced or absent greeting and farewell behaviours;
Lack of awareness and understanding of socially expected behaviour;
Problems losing at games, turn-taking and understanding 'changing the
rules';
May appear unaware or uninterested in what other people are interested in
Unable to adapt style of communication to social situations, for example,
May be overly formal or inappropriately familiar.
Subtle difficulties in understanding other's intentions; may take things literally
and misunderstand sarcasm or metaphor
Makes comments without awareness of social niceties or hierarchies;
Unusually negative response to the requests of others (demand avoidant
behaviour)
EYE CONTACT; POINTING & OTHER GESTURES:
Poorly integrated gestures, lack of facial expressions, body orientation, avoiding eye contact
IMAGINATION:
History of a lack of ideas and flexible social imaginative play and creativity, although scenes seen on visual media (for example, television) may be re-enacted.
RESTRICTED/RIGID INTERESTS & REPETITIVE BEHAVIOURS:
Repetitive 'stereotypical' movements such as hand flapping, body rocking
while standing, spinning, finger flicking
Preference for highly specific interests or hobbies
A strong adherence to rules or fairness that leads to argument
Highly repetitive behaviours or rituals that negatively affect the person's
daily activities
Excessive emotional distress at what seems trivial to others, for example,
change in routine
Dislike of change, which often leads to anxiety or other forms of distress
including aggression
Over or under reaction to sensory stimuli, for example, textures, sounds,
smells
Excessive reaction to taste, smell, texture or appearance of food and/or
extreme food fads
OTHER FACTORS/CONCERNS:
Unusual profile of skills and deficits
Social or motor coordination skills poorly developed, while particular areas of knowledge, reading or vocabulary skills are advanced.
Social and emotional development more immature than other areas of development.
Excessive trusting (naivety& vulnerability),
Lack of common sense,
Less independent than peers.
Useful Contacts for ASD include:
